well what's going to happen is the trend

and some of the companies that are going

maura going bankrupt we're going to have

now we see the be EA they released their
third
estimate of the GDP was from point seven

then they revised it to one point two

we're going to bring this up to one

we can live in an RV it's a lot cheaper

where the GDP number is consistent over

four one point seven point nine I mean
it seems like they're trying to convince

and if it is we're in a lot of trouble
now the Federal Reserve denounced that
all the banks they pass their stress

to go and it looks like they're fine so
what these banks are doing right now
they are going to buy back their own
stocks three of the big
Wall Street banks announced they were

Chase they led the pack where they were

four billion over the next 12 months to

Citigroup they were projected to buy

Bank of America around twelve billion
now the mega banks on Wall Street are

the Harvard Business Review William
Lanzo Nick wrote the following five

most Americans are not sharing in the

gains good jobs keep disappearing and

insecure and underpaid corporate
profitability is not translating into
widespread economic prosperity the
allocation of corporate profits to stock
buybacks deserves much of the blame
consider the four hundred and forty nine
companies in the S&P 500 index that were
publicly listed from 2003 through 2012
during that period these companies use
54 percent of their earnings a total of
two point four trillion to buy back
their own stock almost all through
purchases on the open market
dividends dividends absorbed an
additional 37 percent of their earnings
that left very little for investment in
productive capabilities or higher

no federal regulator has yet to explain
the banks are allowed to operate their

own as dark pools and trade in their own

what does this mean
well they have the ability to manipulate

this is not going to help the economy

they're getting prepared for an economic

now there's many traders out there
financial pundits and they're all going

former FX trader a fund manager Richard

he's worried he's worried about

packed on a staggering amount of debt so
in 2007 during this debt bubble crisis
there was about a hundred and forty nine
trillion dollars worth of global debt
ten years later it stands at two hundred
and seventeen trillion put another way
the world has packed on another 68
trillion in debt since the last debt

world has risen from two hundred and
seventy six percent in 2007 to three
hundred and twenty seven percent why
does this matter because this debt was
built on the back of low interest rates
in the last 10 years bond yields have
fallen dramatically thanks to the
endless central bank intervention in the
US Treasuries it hit an all-time low in
Europe and Japan sovereign bond yields
actually went to zero or even negative
as far out as ten years so we have a
massive debt bubble based on interest
rates remaining at or near record lows
globally central banks have sent a clear

bankers are coalescing around the
message that the cost of money is headed

near zero interest rates where
appropriate Bank of England governor
Mark Carney suggested that the time is
nearing for an increase Janet yellen's
that her policy tightening is on track
Canada's Stephen polos reiterated he may

the world debt to GDP is around three
hundred twenty seven percent all of this
debt was issued at a time when bond
yields bond yields were falling central
bankers now want bond yields to rise so
when we look at this you can see that
what are they trying to do are they

without the central banks manipulating
